comments.commentBody: The man with the nuclear launch codes...
Here, as elsewhere, the observation to make is "So many leakers! So much to leak!"
I'm sorry but if people bother to read this entire article, it sounds to me like Trump is on to something. This isn't good for Obama.

How many investigations can Washington pull off at one time?  By conceding that you'd want to know what the probable cause was, proves that just by making the allegation in the first place, half the battle has already been won.  Not bad for a two sentence tweet.
He will put out any crazy statement to distract from the real issues he is tired of seeing in the news.  Does it every time, it is purposeful.  And media seems to go for it every time.

It is pretty obvious the problem isn't tapped wires as much as "crossed wires."

How embarrassing can it get?
When is enough going to be enough, already? When the nukes have already destroyed the United States?
This presidency is one bad, interminable, forced binge watch of a hack TV show.

Another outrageous tantrum by a man who's willing to create a spin that will cause a major distraction from enacting meaningful legislation.

Trump commonly misinterprets late night cable news as a fodder for his rants. Could these requests be for DOJ wiretaps on the Russians -- not Trump -- as a means of monitoring Russian espionage? Wiretaps of this type were apparently -- source probably classified -- used to monitor Mr. Flynn's conversations with the Russians. With a vivid imagination, taps on Russians that caught Trump adviser conversations could be maliciously spun as an intentional attack on the Trump administration. Taps like those would be on the Russians, not some sort of a fishing expedition into the Trump campaign. If his folks decided to talk to the Russians and got recorded, that's an indication of their bad judgement, not malicious intentions by the Obama administration.

Trump isn't exactly known for the precision of his language. If by "Obama," Trump really means the "Obama administration," then what's not to believe?

As the article notes, the executive branch can obtain a wiretap warrant from an ordinary federal court upon a showing of probable cause that a crime has been committed, or from the FISA court upon a showing that someone in Trump Tower was acting as a foreign agent.

In either event, the "accusation" by Trump, such as it is, is far more damning to him than it is a distraction from his problems in general, but particularly insofar as his Russia problem goes.

If Trump's accusation is that Obama personally orchestrated the wiretapping of Trump Tower outside of any lawful process, it is, like so much that comes out of this man's mouth, another lie that any parent would scold their child for propagating.
It is not baseless.  The denial is the White House did not do it.  The Justice department did.

Trump was probably wiretapped. Why does this shock anyone? Isn’t this a common investigative tool?

The FBI had an investigation and was trying to collect evidence. Since the investigation involved a foreign government, the FBI worked through a FISA court. Their first request was turned down and a second, more specific, request was approved.

Really, the only question is whether Obama “ordered” the investigation and wiretapping. He probably ordered the investigation and let the FBI pursue the wiretapping request. Note that Obama has not actually denied that Trump was wiretapped.

Perhaps that only controversy is whether the wiretapping continued after it had been determined that there was no connection between the Trump servers and those at the Russian bank.

Don't be like Trump.  Read the Constitution, with particular attention to the definition of treason.  It's very narrow, because the people who wrote it were tired of the British using the word very loosely and then accusing them of it.  Trump is guilty of a lot of things, but treason isn't one of them.
Nixon was also intrinsic to the McCarthy episode.

Trump continues to be crazy like a fox. He has succeeded in lying so much and operating so entirely without facts that America has become (so long as he has the bully pulpit) a fact-free zone where he has the power to make policy on the basis of whatever he reads on Breitbart or sees on Fox News or fantasizes in the thin skin that seems to do so much of his thinking for him. Down the middle news organization then report that, as in this case, Obama "denies" Trumps allegation. But Trump will always win a he-said she-said showdown, since he is willing to go beyond all propriety and sense of decency or patriotism in order to drown out any counter argument or fact. It's a dangerous time.

Having someone this volatile as the Commander in Chief is scary.  On the same page as this article, is another one outlining the serious threat posed by North Korea.  Does anyone think Trump has the capabilities and gravitas to deal with the real national security issues facing us?  Mr. Trump has made shattering accusations -ones it is unlikely he can substantiate.  His recklessness is breathtaking.  If there was any wire tapping due to the investigations surrounding Russia's activities, as the article states, they would not have been ordered by President Obama.   Mr. Trump is lashing out because he cannot control the narrative.  I feel the man in unstable.

Just imagine what Trump would be doing if the Democrats had gotten together on election day and held a secret meeting where it was decided their party would block any and all attempts of the newly sworn-in administration to govern. (Sound familiar?)  Or if the Democrats were to go so far as denying his pick for Supreme Court to have their confirmation hearing.  Now if that had happened Trump might have good reason to gripe.

Perhaps 'the  donalt', jarred and that Pooti fellow, and his 'crewe' were recorded in perpetuity claiming their rightful place to, dare I say it, rule the world... Tis no minor matter sooner or later they will come to me... eventually

at this point of american history, i'm not sure the following sentiments carry the same ...weight? ...meaning? -the same gravity? -that they might otherwise, but:

1) this is absolutely surreal

2) and that it's Russia, and that so many 'patriotic' americans seemingly have to be convinced the Russians do not share our interests; and that they are a threat to our very freedom -the fact this has to be argued to self-described 'patriots' -this -THIS!- proves this is surreal

3) and that up is down, north is south and day is night

I'm not paranoid, I am persecuted!

It's a line that was a sort of joke used whenever someone pretty obviously mistaken or guilty claimed unfairness back in the 70's. It is made funnier by the fact that it can actually be true and usually is when the person being persecuted is powerless to defend themselves.

I'm sure someone has already said this, but in the off chance I'm wrong, I'd like to ask my NY neighbors this question: doesn't this reek of desperation? I mean, perhaps I'm indulging in wishful thinking here, but doesn't it seem like The Thing in the Oval Office is reaching the end of its rope? I know I'm reaching the end of mine. The difference between it and I, perhaps, (besides at least two universes) is that I won't let go once I get to the end. This is just too funny. It's like a train wreck full of bloodied accidental comedians. I can't tear my attention away. As many a comic has said for many years regarding The Creature from the Orange Lagoon, you can't make this stuff up. No one would believe it.

More evidence of Trump's paranoia and delusions!
Scary accusations with nothing to back them up.

The deflection argument doesn't work.

Today was March 4, trump day.

There were pro-trump rallies all over the country, but what was the media talking about, his tweets. Why deflect attention away from your rallies?

Unfortunately, a better explanation is that he woke up at 6 AM, came across the Breitbart article, got bent out of shape and started tweeting,

This is our president folks, God help us all.
Small crowds at those rallies

No, the most likely explanation is that he is not fit for office. Trump has much in common with the home-grown mentally ill terrorists shooting people at the mall--reckless, with lack of self-control and good judgement. Mix in paranoia and when do we finally admit the man is too sick and too dangerous to be president? This chaos is just prelude to worse.

My Lord, the bar is set so low on Trump's behavior that a snake would have a hard time slithering under it. His speech was upbeat, but mostly empty of content and filled with wild promises to fix everything including things which really aren't currently broken. Still, he got enthusiastic applause and much praise when all he did was manage not to act crazy for one full hour - and a few seconds.
yes, agree, pretty obvious he was scripted and controlled, and his baseline personality was partly kept in the cage ...
Wonderful writing! "...a snake would have a hard time slithering under it." Exquisite.
